start-view.title: How do I get started?
start-view.body:
Welcome to MonaWallet!

MonaWallet connects directly to the Monacoin network. There are no accounts or usernames with MonaWallet. Instead, you will have a "wallet" where you will store your money. It's just like the physical wallet you put your cash in, except that it exists only on the internet and holds digital money.

If this is your first time using MonaWallet, simply choose "Create New Wallet" to start.

If you have used MonaWallet before and would like to use the same wallet, choose "Recover Wallet" and prepare to enter the Paper Key for the wallet you would like to restore.

send-bitcoin.title: How can I send Monacoin?
send-bitcoin.body:
To send money to someone you need to enter their Monacoin address. There are three different ways to enter this information depending on how you received it:

  • If you are presented with a QR code, press the "scan" button and scan the QR code.
  • If you receive an address through email or text, copy the address to your device's clipboard and press the "paste" button.
  • If you receive the address another way, tap the "To" label and use the keyboard to enter the address.

Once you have entered the payment address, tap the "Amount" label and enter the amount you wish to send. The button to the right will allow you to toggle the view between the amount of Monacoin to be sent or another currency.

If you would like to save a note about this transaction, tap the "Memo" label. This note will only be visible to you, and will not be sent together with the transaction.

Important: If Monacoin is sent to the wrong address, it can not be refunded. When sending Monacoin, always check to make sure the address you are sending to is the same as the one that was given to you (comparing the first 5 or 6 digits is usually sufficient to make sure you are using the correct address).

receive-bitcoin.title: How do I receive Monacoin?
receive-bitcoin.body:
If you would like to receive Monacoin from someone, you will need to give them your Monacoin address. There are a few ways to do this:

  • Show them the "Receive Money" screen in your MonaWallet app, and let them scan your QR code.
  • Press the "Share" button under the QR code to send them your address via email or text message.
  • Tap the QR code to copy your address to your device's memory. You can now paste your address into a website or other app.

The Monacoin address shown on your receive address will change every time you receive money, but old addresses will continue to work.

Important: If Monacoin is sent to the wrong address, it can not be refunded. When sharing your address, always check to make sure the address you give out is the same as the one shown under your QR code (comparing the first 5 or 6 digits is usually sufficient to make sure you are using the correct address).

request-amount.title: How do I use the "Request an Amount" screen?
request-amount.body: The QR code you use to receive money in MonaWallet can contain only your Monacoin address, or it can also specify the amount of money that should be sent. If you use the “request an amount” feature, the amount of money you enter will be included in the QR code. When someone scans your QR code, the amount to send will automatically be filled out, so the sender doesn’t have to enter it themselves. This makes it easier to specify how much money should be sent, and prevent mistakes when trying to receive a specific amount of money.

security-center.title: What is the security center?
security-center.body:
The Security Center allows you to manage additional security features for your MonaWallet.

6-digit PIN

This PIN is used to unlock your wallet and send money. It prevents other people from accessing your MonaWallet in case you let someone else use your phone.

Paper key

If you ever lose or upgrade your phone, you will need your Paper Key to restore your wallet on another device. It is not possible to recover your wallet if you lose both your phone and Paper Key, so write down your Paper Key and keep it safe!

Fingerprint / Touch ID

While the 6-digit PIN is required to secure your wallet, you can also use your device's fingerprint reader for convenience and added security. Using your fingerprint is quicker than entering a PIN, and if people are watching you unlock your wallet they won't be able to see what your PIN is.

This option will only appear if your device has a fingerprint reader.

set-pin.title: Why do I need a PIN?
set-pin.body:
MonaWallet requires you to set a PIN to secure your wallet, separate from your device passcode. You will be required to enter this PIN to view your balance or send money, which keeps your wallet private even if you let someone use your phone or if your phone is stolen by someone who knows your device passcode.

Do not forget your wallet PIN! It can only be reset by using your Paper Key. If you forget your PIN and lose your Paper Key, your wallet will be lost.

enable-fingerprint-authentication.title: What is fingerprint authentication?
enable-fingerprint-authentication.body:
Touch ID on iPhone

Touch ID is available on any iPhone 5s or later, iPad Pro, iPad Air 2, or iPad mini 3 or later. If you have it enabled on your device, you can use your fingerprint to unlock your MonaWallet and authorize transactions instead of entering your passcode. You will still be required to enter your passcode periodically for increased security.

If Touch ID is not enabled on your device, you can enable it in your device's settings under "Touch ID & Passcode.

fingerprint-spending-limit.title: What is the fingerprint/touch ID spending limit?
fingerprint-spending-limit.body:
Fingerprint authorization is a convenient shortcut to authorize payments and view your balance in MonaWallet, but it is not a strong security solution. Security experts have proved it is possible to lift fingerprints from a stolen device and use them to trick that device's fingerprint reader into unlocking the device.

To ensure the majority of your funds are safe in the event your phone is stolen, MonaWallet sets a limit to the amount of money that can be sent with only a fingerprint. If you or anyone else tries to send more than that limit (accumulative), your wallet passcode will be required.

You can change the limit by choosing Fingerprint Authorization Limit in the MonaWallet settings.

paper-key.title: Why do I need to write down my paper key?
paper-key.body:
If you receive a QR code labeled as a "paper wallet" or "Monacoin private key", you can import it into MonaWallet by choosing "Import Wallet" from the MonaWallet menu and following the directions.

Any funds stored on the paper wallet/private key will be sent into your MonaWallet, and will not remain on the paper wallet/private key.

If you want to import a wallet created with MonaWallet, use the "Start/Recover Another Wallet" function instead.

reset-pin-paper-key.title: How do I reset my PIN with my paper key?
reset-pin-paper-key.body:
Every time you create a new wallet with Bread, you are provided with a "Paper Key," which is a list of 12 words that can be used to restore access to your wallet if you ever lose or upgrade your phone. You can also use your Paper Key to reset your wallet PIN if you forget it.

Enter the 12 words from your Paper Key, in order, and you will be able to choose a new PIN.

import-wallet.title: How do I import a wallet?
import-wallet.body:
If you receive a QR code labeled as a "paper wallet" or "Monacoin private key", you can import it into MonaWallet by choosing "Import Wallet" from the MonaWallet menu and following the directions.

Any funds stored on the paper wallet/private key will be sent into your MonaWallet, and will not remain on the paper wallet/private key.

If you want to import a wallet created with MonaWallet, use the "Start/Recover Another Wallet" function instead.

wipe-wallet.title: How do I wipe my wallet?
wipe-wallet.body:
MonaWallet can only have one wallet active at a time. If you choose to start a new wallet or restore an existing wallet, the currently active wallet must be erased first.

If you erase your wallet without writing down its Paper Key, your money will be lost. To prevent this, you must first enter your Paper Key for the currently active wallet to make sure you have it written down correctly. The wallet will then be erased, and you can create a new wallet or restore a previous wallet.

display-currency.title: How does MonaWallet show my balance in my local currency?
display-currency.body:
Money kept in MonaWallet is always stored as Monacoin. MonaWallet uses an exchange rate to show you an estimate of how much your Monacoin is worth in your local currency. When you send a transaction and enter the amount to send in your local currency, MonaWallet uses the exchange rate to calculate how much Monacoin to send.

It's possible people using other wallets are using different exchange rates, so the balance sent/received might be slight different than what other person sees.

Since the exchange rate is always changing, the amount of money in your wallet as quoted in your local currency may change over time. However, your Monacoin balance will not change unless you send or receive Monacoin.

re-scan.title: When should I sync the blockchain?
re-scan.body:
Your MonaWallet connects directly to the Monacoin network. This improves security and privacy, but also means sometimes your MonaWallet can get out of sync with the network.

Syncing with the blockchain can take a lot of time, and usually isn't necessary. If someone sent you money and it shows as confirmed in the blockchain yet it is not appearing in your wallet, your wallet may be out of sync. First check to make sure the address the money was sent to is correct.

If you are trying to send money and constantly get error messages that your transaction was rejected, it could also mean your wallet is out of sync.

In either of this cases, using this feature will rescan the blockchain to find your money and display it properly in your wallet.

recover-wallet.title: How do I recover my wallet?
recover-wallet.body:
Every time you create a new wallet with MonaWallet, you are provided with a "Paper Key," which is a list of 12 words that can be used to restore access to your wallet if you ever lose or upgrade your phone. Your wallet exists only on your phone, and the Paper Key is the only way to restore your wallet if you lose your phone.

To recover your wallet, enter the 12 words, in order, from your Paper Key.

transaction-details.title: What are the transaction details?
transaction-details.body:
This screen shows details about the transaction:

Status

If the transaction status is "complete," then the transaction has successfully gone through. If this is a transaction you sent, the money is now in the wallet of the recipient. If this is a transaction you received, the money is now in your wallet, ready to be spent.

If the status is not yet complete, this will show the current progress. If you are receiving the transaction, you will see an indicator once it is safe to spend the funds.

Memo

Here you can attach a note to the transaction to remind yourself what it was for. This memo will not be shared with anyone else and is only visible to you, but you can edit it at any time, even after the transaction has completed.

Amount

This shows detailed information about how much Monacoin was sent, how much it was worth at the time, and other details about your balance.

Other

At the bottom of this screen you will find additional technical details about the transaction. The Monacoin transaction ID can be used as proof that a payment was made.

wallet-disabled.title: Why is my wallet disabled?
wallet-disabled.body:
If you enter an incorrect wallet PIN too many times, your wallet will become disabled for a certain amount of time. This is to prevent someone else from trying to guess your PIN by quickly making many guesses. If your wallet is disabled, wait until the time shown and you will be able to enter your PIN again.

If you continue to enter the incorrect PIN, the amount of time you will have to wait in between attempts will increase. Eventually, the app will reset and you can start a new wallet.

If you have the paper key for your wallet, you can use it to reset your PIN by choosing the appropriate option on the lock screen.

write-phrase.title: Why do I need to write down my paper key?
write-phrase.body:
Your MonaWallet connects directly to the Monacoin network, where your wallet is stored. The "keys" to access your wallet are securely stored in your phone and nowhere else. MonaWallet will provide you with a unique "Paper Key," which is a list of 12-words which can be used to recreate the keys to your wallet. If you ever lose or upgrade your phone, this "Paper Key" is required to regain access to your Monacoin.

Please write down each word, in order, on a piece of paper. We recommend storing your Paper Key in a safe, safety deposit box at a bank, or wherever you might keep passports, birth certificates, or other important documents. Anyone who has your Paper Key can access your money, even if they don't have your wallet PIN, so keep it private and don't show it to others!

confirm-phrase.title: Why is my wallet disabled?
confirm-phrase.body:
If you enter an incorrect wallet PIN too many times, your wallet will become disabled for a certain amount of time. This is to prevent someone else from trying to guess your PIN by quickly making many guesses. If your wallet is disabled, wait until the time shown and you will be able to enter your PIN again.

If you continue to enter the incorrect PIN, the amount of time you will have to wait in between attempts will increase. Eventually, the app will reset and you can start a new wallet.

If you have the paper key for your wallet, you can use it to reset your PIN by choosing the appropriate option on the lock screen.

How-to-import-a-wallet-using-a-recovery-.title: How to import a wallet using a recovery phrase
How-to-import-a-wallet-using-a-recovery-.body:
When you launch MonaWallet for the first time, you will be given the option to create a new wallet or to recover a wallet. If you have a 12 word recovery phrase from a previous wallet that you would like to import, select recover wallet and then enter the phrase. After that has completed, the wallet will need to sync in order to collect all the information it needs about your balance. Initial syncing can take many hours so please prepare to leave the app open for an extended period of time.

If you wish to import a wallet using a recovery phrase but you already have an active account in Bread, you will need to follow the directions to wipe the wallet before beginning the process above. If the wallet you are wiping has funds, be sure to write down the 12 word recovery phrase for the existing wallet (which can be found in the Security Center) before loading the recovery phrase for the wallet you wish to import.

What-are-push-notifications.title: What are push notifications?
What-are-push-notifications.body: If you enable push notifications, MonaWallet will have the ability to notify you of wallet activity even when you don't have the MonaWallet app open. If you would like to be notified immediately every time you receive a payment or some other action completes, turn on this feature. If you do not want to be notified at all unless you have the MonaWallet app open, turn off push notifications.

Why-does-it-cost-money-to-send-a-transac.title: Why does it cost money to send a transaction?
Why-does-it-cost-money-to-send-a-transac.body:
MonaWallet does not charge any fees to send a transaction. However, the Monacoin network does require a fee, called a "transaction fee". This fee is calculated based on the amount of activity in your wallet, and is always displayed to you before you authorize a payment to be sent.

Wallets that receive many small payments before trying to send one large transaction may be charged a higher transaction fee. If possible, combining the payments you receive into a smaller number of larger transactions can keep your transaction fees low.

Why-is-the-amount-sent-different-than-th.title: Why is the amount sent different than the amount received?
Why-is-the-amount-sent-different-than-th.body: Money in your MonaWallet is always held as Monacoin, and the value in your local currency is displayed as an estimate only. The exchange rate used to make this estimate is always fluctuating, and depending on when a transaction is sent or received the estimated value of the transaction can change. It is common for the estimated value of a transaction to be seen differently by the sender and receiver, however the amount of Monacoin sent should not change.

Is-Bread-free.title: Is MonaWallet free?
Is-Bread-free.body: MonaWallet's core product is and always will be 100% free and open source.

Why-did-my-bitcoin-address-change.title: Why did my Monacoin address change?
Why-did-my-bitcoin-address-change.body: Whenever you receive a payment to the address shown, a new address is automatically generated for you. By using a unique address for every transaction, you can increase privacy and security. Old addresses will still continue to work, even if they are no longer displayed in your app.
